intro: Convolvulus cephalophorus, commonly known as the headflower convolvulus, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the bindweed family (Convolvulaceae) and is characterized by its distinctive, showy flowers that resemble small bells. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has heart-shaped leaves with a hairy texture. Its flowering period occurs during the warmer months, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. The species is often found in coastal and inland regions, adapting well to arid and semi-arid environments.
